In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here's how you can implement the function:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump=3) 
    return dt + Dates.Hour(bump)
end

# Throw an error when Date type is passed
try
    timezone_bumper(Date(2022,1,1))
catch e
    @show e
end
```
In the function `timezone_bumper()`, I use the `Dates.Hour()` function to add hours to the DateTime object `dt`. If you pass a Date type instead of a DateTime, an error will be thrown because you cannot add hours to dates only. In the last part, if we call `timezone_bumper(Date(2022,1,1))`, it will throw an error because we're passing a Date type argument.
